terrain.surface: Gravel roads through French Alps. Significant elevation with Alpine scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional French event. Alpine terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: La Resistance is a regional event in French Alps—Alpine terrain with significant elevation. The French Alps scenery is stunning, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic French Alpine gravel race. Worth it for European cyclists. Not a destination race for international travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in France/Europe—yes, the Alps are worth it. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: 66° South Pyrénées. For similar Alpine terrain: Gravel Suisse.

logistics.airport: Geneva (GVA) or Lyon (LYS) depending on location
logistics.lodging_strategy: French Alps has moderate lodging options.
logistics.food: French Alps has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: French Alpine terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: VecchioJo describes riders "huddled in the porch of the refuge at the top of the Col de l'Arpettaz" ready to "throw our kit in the car and high-tail it home" when weather turns brutal. The organized race appears defunct since 2016, leaving self-supported riders to handle French Alps logistics entirely alone. Talloires location on Lake Annecy means tourist-zone pricing without race infrastructure.

length.explanation: The relaxed start atmosphere reflects the distance - Stu Bowers notes "the sun is up and breakfast was enjoyed at an almost sociable hour" with riders "content to sit on scattered hay bails" instead of pre-dawn racing anxiety. 65 miles allows for the social approach organizers Adam Horler and Ross Muir intended, though the related 3-day Tour covers 283km showing this is the restrained option. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: VecchioJo calls French gravel "more rough hewn, chunky and fibrous" than "finely graded miles of hardpacked aggregate" from "American Marketing Dream" riding. On the Route de la Soif, "it can be difficult to control speed on the descents while trying to pick the best line through clusters of rocks," demanding concentration but favoring sustained power over technical skills. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Stu Bowers describes the Col des Glières as "relentlessly steep – 9% average with large chunks over 10%" where "at every hairpin I feel certain the gradient must ease, but it never does." The HC Col de l'Arpettaz adds 14.8km at 8% average. Combined with gravel sectors, this creates "physical reserves" draining alpine punishment throughout 65 miles. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: The 2016 reconnaissance hit "the worst rain Europe had experienced in quite a while" with snow banks blocking the Route de la Soif requiring riders to "shoulder the bike and clamber across." VecchioJo reports losing "feeling in my extremities" on exposed hairpins. September timing avoids peak weather extremes, but mountain conditions change rapidly above treeline. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Riders emerge "out of the tree line in the upper reaches" of Col de l'Arpettaz to "spectacular view of the Aravis Alps – jagged peaks set in a sea of green fields, accompanied by the gentle clang of cowbells." The Haute Savoie location and exposed alpine terrain create significant elevation effects without reaching oxygen-debt extremes. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: VecchioJo describes the Route de la Soif as "real mountain riding and not the place to cock it up" with the mountain's "brooding presence" creating "spectacular and silently foreboding" atmosphere. The route honors French Resistance fighters who died at Glières Plateau, ending at the National Monument and necropolis where 463 fighters made their last stand.

prestige.explanation: Entry was limited to 463 riders - matching the number of Resistance fighters at Glières - but the inaugural 2016 event appears to have folded shortly after. Despite the meaningful WWII tribute and Mavic support with "bright yellow Service Course motos loaded with spare wheels," the race never gained sustained traction in the competitive gravel scene.

race_quality.explanation: The €95 entry included Mavic jerseys and "La Guinguette" lakeside party, with professional wheel support on course. However, riders faced navigation errors and extreme weather bailouts even in the inaugural year. The relaxed "ride not a race" philosophy and subsequent folding suggest organizational challenges despite good intentions and scenic Talloires beach setting.

experience.explanation: Stu Bowers found his "bottles supped dry and legs close to cramp" after the "brutal" Glières climb drained his "physical reserves." The route creates emotional weight through WWII history, spectacular Mont Blanc views from Route de la Soif, and the contrast between Lake Annecy's beauty and alpine suffering above. The experience transforms riders through "real mountain" challenge.

community.explanation: The inaugural atmosphere was "all very relaxed" with riders encouraged to "take some moments at each La Resistance memorial to honour the memory of those who refused to stand down." Organizers Adam Horler and Ross Muir fostered a social vibe over competitive racing, though the limited 463-rider field and subsequent event folding prevented sustained community building.

field_depth.explanation: The 463-rider cap honored historical significance but created a small field. Riders ranged from those on "23mm tyres" and borrowed "tubs that survived Paris-Roubaix" to recreational cyclists on modified road bikes. Despite attracting varied skill levels to the inaugural event, no notable competitive depth or returning elite field developed before the race folded. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: €95 entry included Mavic jersey, La Guinguette party ticket, and professional wheel support on challenging alpine terrain. The first 100 entrants received Mavic caps, and the lakeside finish party encouraged "period costume." The historical significance and French Alps setting provided meaningful value, though the event's brief lifespan limited long-term community investment.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €80-120. VecchioJo recommends "30mm+ tyres" minimum, noting 28mm "right on the limit of acceptability," while Stu Bowers found 40mm ideal for the "clusters of rocks" and loose surfaces. Beyond tire requirements, Talloires sits in expensive Lake Annecy tourist territory. French Alps location means premium costs for lodging, meals, and transport without organized race logistics support. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
